body.p: To His Excellency, the Governor of Kentucky:

Your petitioner, Wm Goodlow, would respectfully state that at the Novr Term 1860 of the City Court of Louisville, he was fined fifty dollars on an indictment for carrying concealed a pistol -- He states that he is a young man & never has been in the habit of Carrying any weapon & it was purely accidental that he had this weapon about him

It was not his purpose to carry a concealed weapon -- He was in Company with three or four of his Young friends at the Commercial Hotel, (where yr petitioner had been boarding) & where he was well acquainted -- at the time, the pistol, which belonged to the Hotel, was laying on a table, & the young friends & petitioner were playing innocently together, when your petitioner slipped the pistol into his pocket to play off a joke; & when he afterwards left the Hotel, he forgot all about having the pistol & it was found in his pocket & he was indicted & fined for it as above stated.

He prays your Excellency, therefore, to Exercise towards him your clemency and to remit the fine, & especially as your petitioner is of limited means, dependant on his salary in a merchandizing house for his support; and as in duty bound, he ever will &c
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 17th day of Novr 1860.
Jos Clement. J. P. J. C
The undersigned citizens of of Louisville unite in asking a remission of the fine mentioned in this Petition

Jos Clement.
P A N Bradley
Thos Anderson & Co
H. E. Stucky
T. L Ashfordss
Wm Teasdale
John Dagler

From Information which I have received I beleive the statements in the Petition are True I know the Petitioner is a worthy, Industriious & well behaved young Gentleman & that his case presents strong claims for Executive clemency.

Louisville C Ct
Remitted
B, M,
$50. } concealed Weapons
Wm Goodlow
Issd Nov. 22. 1860
